front:
Which of these is not a characteristic of fitness? 
A. Fitness is environment-specific.
B. Fitness is species-specific.
C. Higher reproductive rate means higher fitness.
D. Fitness should be measured across several generations.
back: Answer: Higher reproductive rate means higher fitness.

front:
Ecology is the scientific study of interactions among organisms and their __________. 
A. habitat
B. niche
C. environment
D. population

"Enquiry into plants" is a book written by __________. 
A. Theophrastus
B. Linnaeus
C. Malthus
D. Humboldt

Which of these is not a kind of selection? 
A. Directional
B. Stochastic
C. Disruptive
D. Stabilising

Ecology is the scientific study of __________ that determine the distribution and abundance of organisms. 
A. statics
B. interactions
C. dynamics
D. habitat

Which of these is not a step in natural selection? 
A. Variation
B. Underpopulation
C. Struggle for existence
D. Survival of the fittest

Which of these is not a characteristic of fitness? 
A. Fitness is environment-specific.
B. Fitness is species-specific.
C. Fitness works on traits such as size and speed.
D. Fitness should be measured across several generations.
back: Answer: Fitness works on traits such as size and speed.

front:
In the Greek word root of Ecology, Oikos refers to __________. 
A. household
B. preservation
C. environment
D. study

In the Greek word root of Ecology, logos refers to __________. 
A. household
B. preservation
C. environment
D. study

Who amongst these is considered the father of Biogeography? 
A. Theophrastus
B. Linnaeus
C. Malthus
D. Humboldt

For more diversity, the level of disturbance should be __________. 
A. less
B. intermediate
C. more
D. None of these

Hierarchy emerges almost inevitably through a wide variety of evolutionary processes, for the simple reason that hierarchical structures are __________. 
A. perfect
B. imperfect
C. stable
D. unstable

"Groups of actually or potentially interbreeding natural populations which are reproductively isolated from other such groups" is a definition of __________. 
A. cells
B. species
C. ecosystems
D. biomes

The emergent principle can be stated as __________. 
A. Whole = Sum of parts
B. Whole < Sum of parts
C. Whole > Sum of parts
D. None of these

There is more biodiversity in areas with __________. 
A. less competition and less predation
B. less competition and more predation
C. more competition and more predation
D. more competition and less predation
back: Answer: more competition and more predation

front:
The mitochondrion is a/an __________. 
A. sub cellular organelle
B. cell
C. tissue
D. organ

"The diversity that exists among different geographies" is __________. 
A. alpha biodiversity
B. beta biodiversity
C. gamma biodiversity
D. delta biodiversity

"The diversity that exists with an ecosystem" is __________. 
A. alpha biodiversity
B. beta biodiversity
C. gamma biodiversity
D. delta biodiversity

The hierarchical system was given by __________. 
A. Simon
B. Watson
C. Hutchinson
D. Humboldt

The laboratory approach to ecology uses __________. 
A. equation
B. models
C. observations
D. experiments

I observe a bird take a tick out of another bird's head and eat it. In the social context, this behavior is known as __________. 
A. Tick Hunting
B. Auto Grooming
C. Allo Grooming
D. Foraging

The scientific study of animal behavior is known as __________. 
A. Behaviorism
B. Ecology
C. Ethology
D. Prey-Predator Dynamics

Trampling of grass due to movement of animals is an example of __________. 
A. Mutualism
B. Amensalism
C. Commensalism
D. Protocooperation

Birds on a giraffe is an example of __________. 
A. Colony
B. Commensalism
C. Protocooperation
D. Allelopathy

I observe a monkey take a tick out of another monkey's head and eat it. In the social context, this behavior would be called __________. 
A. Tick Hunting
B. Auto Grooming
C. Allo Grooming
D. Foraging

Hamilton's rule can be stated as __________. 
A. rB < C
B. rB > C
C. rB = C
D. rB + C = 0

Egrets with buffaloes are an example of __________. 
A. Colony
B. Commensalism
C. Protocooperation
D. Allelopathy

The interaction between exotic shrubs and trees through the action of seed predators is an example of __________. 
A. Infraspecific Competition
B. Apparent Competition
C. Disguised Competition
D. Harmonious Competition

Harmonious interaction occurs where __________. 
A. at least one participant is benefited
B. at least one participant is unharmed
C. both participants are benefited
D. both participants are unharmed

An inventory of behaviors exhibited by an animal during a behavior exercise is called __________. 
A. Ecogram
B. Ethogram
C. Behaviourogram
D. Animalogram

Tree --> Frugivorous Birds --> Hawk represents __________. 
A. Upright Pyramid of Numbers
B. Inverted Pyramid of Numbers
C. Spindle Pyramid of Numbers
D. Dumbbell Pyramid of Numbers

If we all became vegetarians, we'll be able to support our large populations. This can be explained through __________. 
A. 10% Rule
B. 1% Rule
C. Trophic Cascade
D. Biodiversity

Consider the food chain: Grass --> Grasshopper --> Frog --> Snake --> Hawk. As we move up the food chain, __________. 
A. available energy decreases
B. available energy increases
C. available energy remains the same
D. available energy Is zero everywhere

Glacial lakes are typical examples of __________. 
A. Eutrophic Lakes
B. Hypereutrophic Lakes
C. Oligotrophic Lakes
D. Mesotrophic Lakes

Trees --> Birds --> Parasites --> Hyperparasites represents __________. 
A. Upright Pyramid of Numbers
B. Inverted Pyramid of Numbers
C. Spindle Pyramid of Numbers
D. Dumbbell Pyramid of Numbers

Consider the food chain: Grass --> Grasshopper --> Frog --> Snake --> Hawk. In the food chain, __________. 
A. Frog is a Producer
B. Frog Is a Consumer and Carnivore
C. Frog Is a Consumer and Herbivore
D. Frog Is a Decomposer
back: Answer: Frog Is a Consumer and Carnivore

front:
At the compensation point, __________. 
A. Photosynthesis = Respiration
B. Photosynthesis < Respiration
C. Photosynthesis > Respiration
D. Photosynthesis = 0

Consider the food chain: Grass --> Grasshopper --> Frog --> Snake --> Hawk. In this food chain, __________. 
A. more number of Hawks than Grasshopper can be supported
B. more number of Grasshoppers than Hawks can be supported
C. an equal number of Hawks and Grasshopper can be supported
D. None of these
back: Answer: more number of Grasshoppers than Hawks can be supported

front:
Consider the food chain: Grass --> Grasshopper --> Frog --> Snake --> Hawk. In this food chain, __________. 
A. Hawk is a Producer
B. Hawk Is a Consumer and Carnivore
C. Hawk Is a Consumer and Herbivore
D. Hawk Is a Decomposer
back: Answer: Hawk Is a Consumer and Carnivore

front:
Net Primary Productivity is given by __________. 
A. APAR X LUE
B. APAR + LUE
C. APAR - LUE
D. APAR / LUE

Which of these is not a measure of absolute population density? 
A. Total Count
B. Pelt Count
C. Capture-Recapture Method
D. Removal Method

The juvenile mortality rate is the annual number of deaths of juveniles per __________. 
A. 100 Births
B. 1000 Births
C. 100 Live Births
D. 1000 Live Births

_____ is how close the measured values are to the correct values 
A. Accuracy
B. Precision
C. Bias
D. Variance

__________ employs a simple rule of selecting every kth unit starting with a number chosen at random from 1 to k as the random start. 
A. Simple Random Sampling
B. Systematic Sampling
C. Stratified Sampling
D. Multistage Sampling

Cover board surveys are typically used for sampling __________. 
A. Herpetofauna
B. Fishes
C. Large Mammals
D. Carnivores

The minimum replacement level fertility for a population to grow should be greater than __________. 
A. 1
B. 2
C. 3
D. 4

The logistic growth curve, when plotted, appears __________. 
A. I Shaped
B. J Shaped
C. S Shaped
D. O Shaped

Pan traps are used for sampling __________. 
A. Bees
B. Butterflies
C. Non-Pollinator Insects
D. Pollinator Insects

A sampling procedure such that each possible combination of sampling units out of the population has the same chance of being selected is referred to as __________. 
A. Simple Random Sampling
B. Systematic Sampling
C. Stratified Sampling
D. Multistage Sampling

Which of these is true? 
A. Physiological Longevity > Ecological Longevity
B. Physiological Longevity = Ecological Longevity
C. Physiological Longevity < Ecological Longevity
D. Physiological Longevity >= Ecological Longevity

Importance value varies from __________. 
A. 0 to 10
B. 0 to 50
C. 0 to 100
D. 0 to 300

A species found most frequently in a particular community, but also present occasionally in others is called __________. 
A. Accidental Species
B. Indifferent Species
C. Selective Species
D. Exclusive Species

Which of these depicts correctly the lithosere primary succession? 
A. Rock --> Crustose Lichen --> Foliose Lichen --> Moss --> Herbaceous Stage --> Shrub --> Woodland --> Climax
B. Rock --> Foliose Lichen --> Crustose Lichen --> Moss --> Herbaceous Stage --> Shrub --> Woodland --> Climax
C. Moss --> Crustose Lichen --> Foliose Lichen --> Rock --> Herbaceous Stage --> Shrub --> Woodland --> Climax
D. Rock --> Crustose Lichen --> Foliose Lichen --> Shrub --> Herbaceous Stage --> Moss --> Woodland --> Climax
back: Answer: Rock --> Crustose Lichen --> Foliose Lichen --> Moss --> Herbaceous Stage --> Shrub --> Woodland --> Climax

front:
Importance value can be written as __________. 
A. Relative Density + Relative Frequency X Relative Dominance
B. Relative Density X Relative Frequency + Relative Dominance
C. Relative Density + Relative Frequency + Relative Dominance
D. Relative Density X Relative Frequency X Relative Dominance
back: Answer: Relative Density + Relative Frequency + Relative Dominance

front:
Lithosere is an example of __________. 
A. Hydrosere
B. Xerosere
C. Psammosere
D. Halosere

The climax near Tindi village is being controlled by disturbance by cattle. This is an example of __________. 
A. Climatic Climax
B. Edaphic Climax
C. Disclimax
D. Catastrophic Climax

A climax caused by wildfires is an example of __________. 
A. Climatic Climax
B. Edaphic Climax
C. Disclimax
D. Catastrophic Climax

Which of these is correct? 
A. Fundamental Niche > Realized Niche
B. Fundamental Niche = Realized Niche
C. Fundamental Niche < Realized Niche
D. Fundamental Niche >= Realized Niche

When compared to generalist species, specialist species have __________. 
A. Narrower Niche
B. Broader Niche
C. Same Size Niche
D. None of These

Which of these is not a characteristic of pioneer species? 
A. Ability to Grow on Bare Rocks
B. Ability to Tolerate Extreme Temperatures
C. Large Size
D. Short Lifespan

Scarcity of food is a __________. 
A. Chemical Factor
B. Demographic Factor
C. Push Factor
D. Pull Factor

Good climate is a __________. 
A. Chemical Factor
B. Demographic Factor
C. Push Factor
D. Pull Factor

The movement of individuals away from their place of birth or hatching or seed production into a new habitat or area to survive and reproduce is called __________. 
A. Translocation
B. Migration
C. Dispersal
D. Drifting

"The geographical distribution of a species will be controlled by that environmental factor for which the organism has the narrowest range of tolerance." This is the statement for __________. 
A. Liebig�s Law of the Minimum
B. Liebig�s Law of the Maximum
C. Shelford�s Law of Tolerance
D. Shelford�s Law of Intolerance

"Quick movement over large distances, often across unsuitable terrain" is a description of __________. 
A. Diffusion
B. Secular Dispersal
C. Jump Dispersal
D. Drifting

The regular, seasonal movement of animals, often along fixed routes is called __________. 
A. Translocation
B. Migration
C. Dispersal
D. Drifting

The movement of lions across the Gir landscape is an example of __________. 
A. Diffusion
B. Secular Dispersal
C. Jump Dispersal
D. Drifting

Which of these is not a physical factor of habitat? 
A. Soil
B. Moisture
C. Predators
D. Temperature

Transplantation experiments are used to find __________. 
A. Potential Range
B. Effective Range
C. Actual Range
D. Economic Range

I tried growing vegetables under my teak plantation, but the vegetable plants died out. I should be concerned about __________. 
A. Autophagy
B. Allelophagy
C. Autopathy
D. Allelopathy

Captive breeding is an example of __________. 
A. In-situ conservation
B. Ex-situ conservation
C. In-situ preservation
D. Ex-situ preservation

The "subset of physical and biotic environmental factors that permit an animal (or plant) to survive and reproduce" is the definition of __________. 
A. Habitat
B. Ecosystem
C. Biome
D. Biosphere

We prefer those areas for the creation of a conservation reserve where the level of threat is __________. 
A. Very High
B. Medium
C. Very Low
D. Non-Existent

Which of these is a deterministic factor? 
A. Environmental Variation
B. Forest Fire
C. Death Rate
D. Diseases

The acronym HIPPO does not include __________. 
A. Habitat Loss
B. Habitat Enhancement
C. Invasive Species
D. Human Over Population

Which of these correctly represents the process of habitat fragmentation and loss? 
A. Original Forest --> Dissection --> Perforation --> Fragmentation --> Attrition
B. Original Forest --> Dissection --> Attrition --> Fragmentation --> Perforation
C. Original Forest --> Dissection --> Perforation --> Attrition --> Fragmentation
D. Original Forest --> Dissection --> Fragmentation --> Perforation --> Attrition
back: Answer: Original Forest --> Dissection --> Perforation --> Fragmentation --> Attrition

front:
The acronym HIPPO does not include __________. 
A. Habitat Loss
B. Invasive Species
C. Pollination
D. Pollution

Which of these is a stochastic factor? 
A. Birth Rate
B. Death Rate
C. Population Structures
D. Environmental Fluctuations

According to Leopold, which of these is not a tool of habitat management? 
A. Fire
B. Gun
C. Cattle
D. Sickle

Zoo is an example of __________. 
A. In-situ conservation
B. Ex-situ conservation
C. In-situ preservation
D. Ex-situ preservation

Which of these is a preventive check according to Malthus? 
A. Foresight
B. Vice
C. Misery
D. Flood

Which of these is not a pillar of sustainability? 
A. Environmental Sustainability
B. Economic Sustainability
C. Trans-Boundary Sustainability
D. Social Sustainability

__________ is to identify which potential impacts are relevant to assess. 
A. Screening
B. Scoping
C. Reporting
D. Review

Which of these is a positive check according to Malthus? 
A. Late Marriage
B. War
C. Celibacy
D. Moral Restraint

Which of these is a pillar of sustainability? 
A. Social Sustainability
B. Industrial Sustainability
C. Agricultural Sustainability
D. Trans-Boundary Sustainability

The demographic transition sees a society move from __________. 
A. High Birth Rate, High Death Rate to Low Birth Rate, Low Death Rate
B. Low Birth Rate, High Death Rate to Low Birth Rate, Low Death Rate
C. High Birth Rate, High Death Rate to Low Birth Rate, High Death Rate
D. High Birth Rate, High Death Rate to Low Birth Rate, Low Death Rate
back: Answer: High Birth Rate, High Death Rate to Low Birth Rate, Low Death Rate

front:
The book "An Essay on the Principle of Population" was written by __________. 
A. Darwin
B. Malthus
C. Spencer
D. Owens

The quantum of human impacts is given by __________. 
A. I = P X A X T
B. I = P + A + T
C. I = P + A - T
D. I = P - (A + T)
back: Answer: I = P X A X T

front:
__________ determines which projects or development require a full or partial impact assessment study. 
A. Screening
B. Scoping
C. Reporting
D. Review

According to Malthusian model __________. 
A. Population grows in geometric progression, food supply increases in arithmetic progression
B. Population grows in geometric progression, food supply increases in geometric progression
C. Population grows in arithmetic progression, food supply increases in arithmetic progression
D. Population grows in arithmetic progression, food supply increases in geometric progression
back: Answer: Population grows in geometric progression, food supply increases in arithmetic progression

front:
Mesodebris in the context of plastic debris has fragments of size __________. 
A. > 20mm
B. 5 - 20mm
C. < 5mm
D. < 1mm

The government came up with a regulation that incandescent bulbs be replaced by LED bulbs, so that electricity consumption and release of carbon dioxide from power plants is reduced. In the context change, such an action would be called __________. 
A. Adaptation
B. Mitigation
C. Deceleration
D. Maladaptation

Which of these is not a climatic forcing for Earth? 
A. Changes in plate tectonics
B. Changes in Earth's orbit
C. Changes in Moon's orbit
D. Changes in Sun's orbit

Which of these is not a principle of ecological restoration? 
A. Ecological Integrity
B. Long-term Sustainability
C. Benefits and Engages Scientists
D. Informed by Past and Future

"The ability of a system to adjust to climate change (including climate variability and extremes) to moderate potential damages, to take advantage of opportunities, or to cope with the consequences" is a definition for __________. 
A. Adaptive Response
B. Adaptive Capacity
C. Mitigative Response
D. Mitigative Capacity

Which of these is not a principle of ecological restoration? 
A. Ecological Integrity
B. Short-term Sustainability
C. Benefits and Engages Society
D. Informed by Past and Future

Macrodebris in context of plastic debris has fragments of size __________. 
A. > 20mm
B. 5 - 20mm
C. < 5mm
D. < 1mm

Because of climate change, Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is suffering from frequent droughts. The management has built several artificial water holes for animals, and fills them up regularly with tankers. In the context of climate change, such an action would be called __________. 
A. Adaptation
B. Mitigation
C. Deceleration
D. Maladaptation

"Any changes in natural and human systems that inadvertently increase vulnerability to climatic stimuli; an adaptation that does not succeed in reducing vulnerability but increases it instead" is a definition for __________. 
A. Adaptation
B. Mitigation
C. Maladaptation
D. Malmitigation

Which of these is not a climatic forcing for Earth? 
A. Changes in plate tectonics
B. Changes in Earth's orbit
C. Changes in Sun's orbit
D. Changes in Sun's strength

A pest population is called uncontrolled when __________. 
A. It is increasing
B. It is not decreasing
C. It is causing some economic damage
D. It is causing excessive economic damage
back: Answer: It is causing excessive economic damage

front:
The impact of El Ni�o on fishery collapse in Peru is explained by __________. 
A. Match Hypothesis
B. Mismatch Hypothesis
C. Match-Mismatch Hypothesis
D. None of these

Which of these is correct? 
A. R + G = M + F
B. R + M = G + F
C. R + F + M + G
D. R + G + M + F = 0

Ludwig's ratchet predicts __________. 
A. Decreasing harvesting rate
B. Constant harvesting rate
C. Increasing harvesting rate
D. Fluctuating harvesting rate

A root zone treatment plant is an example of __________. 
A. Phytoremediation
B. Biological Control
C. Biomagnification
D. Bioaccumulation

A pest population is called controlled when __________. 
A. It is increasing
B. It is decreasing
C. It is not causing any economic damage
D. It is not causing excessive economic damage
back: Answer: It is not causing excessive economic damage

front:
A deciduous forest in Madhya Pradesh was converted into a mine. After the mining operations were over, the pits were filled up with water and a lake was created. It is now visited by several migratory birds. This is an example of __________. 
A. Recovery
B. Restoration
C. Enhancement
D. Replacement

A deciduous forest in Madhya Pradesh was converted into a mine. After the mining operations were over, the pits were filled up with soil and species of deciduous forest planted again. This is an example of __________. 
A. Recovery
B. Restoration
C. Enhancement
D. Replacement

Which of these is not an impact of toxic chemicals? 
A. Lethal Effects
B. Sublethal Effects
C. Reduction of Existing Stressors
D. Reduce Fecundity

Which of these is correct? 
A. The maximum sustainable yield is near the beginning of the sigmoid curve
B. The maximum sustainable yield is near the mid point of the sigmoid curve
C. The maximum sustainable yield is near the end of the sigmoid curve
D. None of these
back: Answer: The maximum sustainable yield is near the mid point of the sigmoid curve
